Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro, 2017 National, 2017 Metro, 2015 National, 2015 Metro
Description: Final weight for split sample: group 1 topical modules
Question Text: NA
User Notes:
Some AHS modules are considered to be "topical" as opposed to "core." Topical modules are included on a rotating basis and are usually asked of only half the AHS sample. When a topical module is only asked of half the sample a special weight is provided that must be used for estimating those data items. SP1WEIGHT is only present for records that are in group 1; SP2WEIGHT is only present for records in group 2. Beginning in 2023, some "topical" module questions were embedded into existing "core" modules. Due to this, the 2023 AHS instrument includes "topical" questions that were included in Group 1, Group 2, and the full sample. For more details regarding 2023 "topical" content, including each variable's topic, group, and weight, reference "2023 AHS Topical Content Reference File."
In 2023, Group 1 included Heat Risk and Housing Insecurity; Group 2 included Healthy Homes and Power Outage.
In 2021, Group 1 included the topic Recent Mover and Neighborhood Quality; Group 2 included Pets, Wildfire Risk, Smokers.
In 2019, Group 1 included the topic Food Security and Post-Secondary Education; Group 2 included Accessibility.
In 2017, Group 1 included the topic Commuting; Group 2 included Disaster Planning.
In 2015, Group 1 included the topics Art, Food Security, and Housing Counseling; Group 2 included Healthy Homes.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro
Description: Final weight
Question Text: NA
User Notes:
Each housing unit in the AHS represents itself and a number of other units. In order to develop estimates using the AHS the final weight must be applied to the survey data. The final weight starts with the inverse of the sampling fraction (PWT) and incorporates several adjustment factors that minimize sampling errors and errors from incomplete survey data.

The Noninterview Adjustment Factor increases the weight of each interviewed unit to account for sampled units that were not interviewed. This adjustment is applied to five classes of geography: central cities, urban and rural inside MSAs, urban and rural outside MSAs. Over time the geographic boundaries related to these five classes may be redefined by local or state governments. For National surveys, WEIGHT uses the boundaries as they were officially defined in 1980. For Metro surveys, WEIGHT uses the boundaries as they were defined in the decennial year prior to the survey year.

More information on weighting can be found at www.census.gov/programs-surveys/ahs/tech-documentation/def-errors-changes.html.

WEIGHT may be used with all Metro surveys, and for National survey years 1997, 1999, and 2015 and later. For National survey years 2001 to 2013, WGT90GEO should be used as the final weight.

Description: Flag indicating there is an owner or property manager onsite
Response Codes: 1: 2 to 4 unit building has owner on-site||2: 2 to 4 unit building has manager on-site||3: 5 or more unit building has owner and / or manager on-site||4: No owner / manager on-site||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS in ('1' '2' '3') and BLD in ('04' '05' '06' '07' '08' '09') and (TENURE in ('2' '3') or VACANCY in ('01' '02' '04'))
User Notes: MGRONSITE is determined using OWNHEREQA (Does the owner of the building live in one of the units in this building?), OWNHEREQB (Does the property manager live in one of the units in this building?), and OWNHEREQC (Does the owner or property manger live in one of the units in this building?). OWNHEREQA and OWNHEREQB are asked of multiunit buildings with 2-4 units. OWNHEREQC is asked of buildings with 5 or more units.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro, 2017 National, 2017 Metro, 2015 National, 2015 Metro
Description: Flag indicating owner owns the lot
Response Codes: 1: Yes||2: No||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
Conditions in Universe: MHMOVE <> '1' and COOP = '2' and CONDO = '2' and (BLD = '01' and (TENURE in ('1' '2' '3') or VACANCY in ('01' '02' '03' '04' '05')) or (TENURE = '1' or VACANCY in ('03' '05')))
User Notes: OWNLOT is determined by using information from multiple items, including OWNLOT1, OWNLOT2 and INCS2. OWNLOT in 2013 and earlier was only provided for mobile homes. However, there are other situations where the unit, but not the land, is owned. This sometimes occurs on university property where the unit itself is owned, but the land is rented.

Response Codes: 1: Bathroom is outside unit but inside building||2: Bathroom is outside building||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: Earlier you reported not having a bathroom in your unit, is your bathroom: Outside the apartment or unit, but inside the building? Or Outside the building?
User Notes: This question is only asked when the respondent has earlier reported no bathrooms or half baths. Respondents are then asked a follow-up question if they have access to a bathroom outside of the unit within the building or outside of the building. The instrument name for this variable used to be SHARBATH in 2015 and was changed to BATHEXCLU from 2017 onwards. AHS began imputing BATHEXCLU in 2017.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro, 2017 National, 2017 Metro, 2015 National, 2015 Metro
Description: Type of upkeep problems
Response Codes: 1: Less than 3 upkeep problems||2: 3 or 4 upkeep problems||3: 5 or more upkeep problems
Question Text: NA
User Notes: This item reflects levels of upkeep problems defined by HUD. Moderately inadequate upkeep is defined as having three of four of the following problems: (1) water leaks from the outside, such as from the roof, basement, windows, or doors; (2) leaks from inside structure, such as pipes or plumbing fixtures; (3) holes in the floors; (4) holes or open cracks in the walls or ceilings; (5) more than 8 by 11 inches of peeling paint or broken plaster; or (6) signs of rats in the last 90 days. Severely inadequate upkeep is defined as having at least five of those problems.

Description: Flag indicating if unit had any toilet breakdowns in last 3 months
Response Codes: 1: Yes||2: No||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
User Notes: NOTOIL is determined using IFTLT1 (Was there any time in the past year when your toilet was broken, or stopped up, or otherwise not working so you couldn't use it?) and IFTLT2 (Did that happen at all within the past 3 months?). This question is only asked if the respondent replied that they had a flush toilet. AHS began imputing NOTOIL in 2017.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro, 2017 National, 2017 Metro, 2015 National, 2015 Metro
Description: Number of toilet breakdowns within last 3 months that lasted 6 hours or more
Response Codes: 0: Never broke down for 6 hours||1 : 7: 1 to 7 breakdowns lasting 6 hours or more||8: Eight or more breakdowns lasting 6 hours or more||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
User Notes: NOTOILFREQ is determined using NUM3TLT (How many times in the last 3 months was the toilet not working?) and NUMTLT (How many of those times was it not working for 6 hours or more?). AHS began imputing NUM3TLT and NUMTLT in 2017. While NOTOILFREQ is not imputed directly, its components are and it's edit flag indicates imputation where one or more of its component variables are imputed.

User Notes: PERSONID is an 11-digit variable that serves as a unique identifier for each household member on the Person dataset. The variable is created by concatenating the CONTROL number with a 3-digit, zero-padded person integer, starting with '001' and incrementing by one for each additional person in the housing unit. The PERSONID value for each person will remain the same across survey years.

Description: Line number of SOGI respondent
Response Codes: 1 : 30: 1 to 30||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
User Notes: The "SOGI Respondent" is the respondent at the time that the SOGI questions were asked during the interview. Because the respondent can change, the "SOGI Respondent" may not always be the same person as the respondent who answered other questions about the housing unit during the interview.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro
Description: SOGI respondent gender
Response Codes: 1: Male adult, recorded male at birth (cisgender male)||2: Male adult, recorded female at birth||3: Female adult, recorded female at birth (cisgender female)||4: Female adult, recorded male at birth||5: Transgender identifying adult||6: Uses another term adult||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' and AGE >= 18 and SOGIRESP = PLINE
User Notes:
SOGI Respondents were first asked for their sex recorded at birth. Sex recorded at birth refers to an individual's biological status as male or female. Sex recorded at birth is associated with physical attributes, such as anatomy and chromosomes. Next, they were asked whether they describe themselves as male, female, transgender, or another term they specify. Census then classified them into the 6 response categories.

To create household-level estimates, merge household and person files using the CONTROL variable as the key. Analyses can then be correctly conducted on SOGIRGP, SOGIRSOP, and SOGIRLGBTP by retaining the data where PLINE equals SOGIRESP.

To create household-level estimates, merge household and person files using the CONTROL variable as the key. Analyses can then be correctly conducted on SOGIRGP, SOGIRSOP, and SOGIRLGBTP by retaining the data where PLINE equals SOGIRESP.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro, 2017 National, 2017 Metro, 2015 National, 2015 Metro
Description: Person's interest, dividends, and net rental income (past 12 months)
Response Codes: 0: Does not receive income from interest, dividends or rents||-9999998 : 9999998: -$9,999,998 to $9,999,998||9999999: $9,999,999 or more||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
User Notes: INTP is the sum of amounts reported for INTQ, DIVQ, and RENTQ: Respondents were first asked QINT (In the 12 months prior to the date of the interview did you receive interest from savings, money market funds, CDs, or other interest bearing accounts?), and if they replied yes, were then asked INTQ (What was the amount received?). The same is true of QDIV and DIVQ (Did you have any dividends from stock?), and QRENT and RENTQ (Did you receive net rental income?).

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro, 2017 National, 2017 Metro, 2015 National, 2015 Metro
Description: Person's other income (past 12 months)
Response Codes: 0: Does not receive income from alimony, Workers' Compensation or other||1 : 9999997: $1 to $9,999,997||9999998: $9,999,998 or more||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
User Notes: For all relatives of the reference person, OIP is the sum of amounts reported for worker's compensation, alimony, and any other income not previously reported. When the person is not a relative of the reference person, OIP is the value of their income excluding wages and self-employment income (OTHNRQ). The related items are QWKCMP (In the 12 months prior to the date of the interview did you receive any disability payments such as SSDI, worker's compensation, veteran's disability or other disability payments?), and its follow-up WKCMPQ (What was the amount?); QALIM and ALIMQ (Did you receive alimony or child support?); and QOTHER and OTHERQ (Did you regularly receive income from any other sources, such as Veteran's (VA) payments or unemployment compensation?).

Description: Monthly total mortgage amount (all mortgages)
Question Text: NA
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' and TENURE = '1' and MORTSTAT in ('2' '3' '4' '5')
User Notes: MORTAMT is the sum of PMTAMT (mortgage payment amount) across all mortgages. Some households' property tax and/or homeowner insurance payments are included in a mortgage payment. The property tax and/or homeowner insurance amounts are subtracted from the sum of PMTAMT in such cases. Occasionally the amount of property tax and/or homeowner insurance is greater than the mortgage payment, creating a negative MORTAMT value.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro
Description: Down payment percentage
Response Codes: 0: No down payment||1: Greater than zero to 2 percent||2: 3 to 5 percent||3: 6 to 10 percent||4: 11 to 15 percent||5: 16 to 20 percent||6: 21 to 40 percent||7: 41 to 99 percent||8: 100 percent||9: Made a down payment, amount not reported||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
User Notes:
Respondents could report in either dollars or percentage (DWNAMT - Considering all sources of money, what was the total amount of the down payment? You may answer in dollars or percent.) If reported in dollars (DWNDLR) the value was converted to percent for the microdata. DWNPCT is the Instrument variable used to collect the percentage.

From 2015 to 2019, units that did not have a down payment were considered out of universe for the question. In 2021 units without a down payment are now in universe for the question and are assigned to DWNPAYPCT category 0: no down payment.

In 2015 to 2019, units with down payment dollar amounts that rounded down to zero when converted to a percentage of the purchase price were previously included in DWNPAYPCT's zero category. In 2021 these units with down payments that round down to zero percent are included in DWNPAYPCT category 1: greater than zero to 2 percent.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro, 2017 National, 2017 Metro, 2015 National, 2015 Metro
Description: Type of rental subsidy or reduction (based on respondent report)
Response Codes: 1: Public housing||2: Portable voucher||3: Non-portable voucher||4: Other government subsidy||5: Rent reduction requiring annual recertification not reported elsewhere||6: Rent reduction because household member works for owner||7: Rent reduction because household member related to owner||8: No rental subsidy or reduction||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
Conditions in Universe: (INTSTATUS = '1' and TENURE in ('2' '3')) or (INTSTATUS in ('2' '3') and VACANCY in ('01' '02' '04'))
User Notes:
RENTSUB is determined using multiple items collected during the interview:
1 = Public Housing (if PROJ1 (Is the housing authority your landlord?) or PROJ2 (Is the building owned by the public housing authority?) is reported to be yes)
2 = Portable Voucher (else if VCHER (Does your household have a housing voucher?) and VCHRMOV (Can you use your housing voucher to move to another location?) are reported yes)
3 = Non-Portable Voucher (else if VCHER is yes and VCHRMOV is no, dk, or refused)
4 = Other Federal/State/Local Subsidy (else if SUBRNT1 (Is your rent amount lower because you are in either a Federal, State or local government housing program?) or SUBRNT2 (Does the Federal, State, or local government pay some of the cost of the unit?) are reported yes)
5 = Rent Reduction Requiring Annual Recertification Not Reported Above (else if RENEW (Do you have to re-certify to determine the amount of rent you pay?) is yes)
6 = Rent Reduction Because HH Member Works for Owner (else if RNTADJ1 (Is rent reduced for this unit because someone in the household works for the owner?) is yes)
7 = Rent Reduction Because HH Member Related to Owner (else if RNTADJ2 (Is rent reduced for this unit because someone in the household is related to the owner?) is yes).

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro, 2017 National, 2017 Metro, 2015 National, 2015 Metro
Description: Monthly electric amount
Response Codes: 0: Unit does not use electricity||1: Vacant home: billed separately||2: Occupied or vacant home: included in the rent, site rent, condominium fee, other fee, or other utility bill||3: Occupied home: provided free of charge||4 : 832: $4 to $832||833: $833 or more||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' or (INTSTATUS in ('2' '3') and (VACANCY in ('01' '02' '04') or (VACANCY in ('03' '05') and CONDO = '1')))
User Notes: Monthly electric amount represents average monthly costs paid for electricity. Average monthly costs are estimated from regression models developed from the Residential Energy Consumption Survey (RECS) sponsored by the Department of Energy (DOE). The RECS collects data on electricity consumption and costs, as well as some housing and household characteristics similar to those collected in the AHS. Housing and household characteristics and heating and cooling degree days from the AHS are used as inputs to the models. Separate models are applied to units that use electricity alone and those that use both electricity and natural gas. When electricity is billed separately or can be modeled separately, the models estimate electricity consumption, which is converted into costs with price data. When the electric bill is combined with a utility that cannot be modeled separately (i.e., oil, other fuels, trash, water), the models estimate costs with additional information on either the last bill or the respondent's best estimate of average monthly electric costs. Amounts are for occupied units that use and pay for electricity, where the electricity cost is not included in rent, site rent, condo fee, or other fee, or included in another utility cost. Costs are not collected for vacant units, but information is collected on whether the unit would be billed separately for electricity or if the electric costs would be included in the rent, condo fee, or other charges.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro, 2017 National, 2017 Metro, 2015 National, 2015 Metro
Description: Monthly gas amount
Response Codes: 0: Unit does not use gas||1: Vacant home: billed separately||2: Occupied or vacant home: included in the rent, site rent, condominium fee, other fee, or other utility bill||3: Occupied home: provided free of charge||4 : 832: $4 to $832||833: $833 or more||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' or (INTSTATUS in ('2' '3') and (VACANCY in ('01' '02' '04') or (VACANCY in ('03' '05') and CONDO = '1')))
User Notes: Monthly gas amount represents average monthly costs paid for gas (note: the variable GASSOURCE indicates whether gas is delivered through underground pipes or is bottled gas). Average monthly costs are estimated from regression models developed from the Residential Energy Consumption Survey (RECS) sponsored by the Department of Energy (DOE). The RECS collects data on gas consumption and costs, as well as some housing and household characteristics similar to those collected in the AHS. Separate models were developed for piped natural gas and bottled liquid petroleum gas (propane). Housing and household characteristics and heating and cooling degree days from the AHS are used as inputs to the models. When gas is billed separately or can be modeled separately, the models estimate gas consumption, which is converted into costs with price data. When the gas bill is combined with a utility that cannot be modeled separately (i.e., oil, other fuels, trash, water), the models estimate costs with additional information on either the last bill or the respondent's best estimate of average monthly gas costs. Amounts are for occupied units that use and pay for gas, where the gas cost is not included in rent, site rent, condo fee, or other fee, or included in another utility cost. Costs are not collected for vacant units, but information is collected on whether the unit would be billed separately for gas or if the gas costs would be included in the rent, condo fee, or other charges.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro, 2017 National, 2017 Metro, 2015 National, 2015 Metro
Description: Monthly oil amount
Response Codes: 0: Unit does not use fuel oil||1: Vacant home: billed separately||2: Occupied or vacant home: included in the rent, site rent, condominium fee, other fee, or other utility bill||3: Occupied home: provided free of charge||4 : 832: $4 to $832||833: $833 or more||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: In the last year, what was the total cost for fuel oil?
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' or (INTSTATUS in ('2' '3') and (VACANCY in ('01' '02' '04') or (VACANCY in ('03' '05') and CONDO = '1')))
User Notes: Monthly oil amount represents average monthly costs paid for oil. Respondents who use oil are asked to estimate the total cost for fuel oil in the past 12 months. The total amount for the past 12 months is divided by 12 to obtain the average monthly amount. Amounts are for occupied units that use and pay for oil, where the oil cost is not included in rent, site rent, condo fee, or other fee, or included in another utility cost. Costs are not collected for vacant units, but information is collected on whether the unit would be billed separately for oil or if the oil costs would be included in the rent, condo fee, or other charges.

Description: Monthly amount for other fuels

Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' or (INTSTATUS in ('2' '3') and (VACANCY in ('01' '02' '04') or (VACANCY in ('03' '05') and CONDO = '1')))
User Notes: Monthly amount for other fuels represents average monthly costs paid for other fuels (i.e., wood, coal, kerosene, or any other fuel). Respondents who use other fuels are asked to estimate the total cost for other fuels in the past 12 months. The total amount for the past 12 months is divided by 12 to obtain the average monthly amount. Amounts are for occupied units that use and pay for other fuels, where the cost for other fuels is not included in rent, site rent, condo fee, or other fee, or included in another utility cost. Costs are not collected for vacant units, but information is collected on whether the unit would be billed separately for other fuels or if the other fuel costs would be included in the rent, condo fee, or other charges.

Description: Monthly trash amount
Response Codes: 0: Unit does not use trash services||1: Vacant home: billed separately||2: Occupied or vacant home: included in the rent, site rent, condominium fee, other fee, or other utility bill||3: Occupied home: provided free of charge||4 : 832: $4 to $832||833: $833 or more||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: In the last year, what was the total cost for garbage and trash collection?
User Notes: Monthly trash amount represents average monthly costs paid for garbage and trash collection. Respondents are asked to estimate the total cost for garbage and trash collection in the past 12 months. The total amount for the past 12 months is divided by 12 to obtain the average monthly amount. Amounts for occupied units that pay for garbage and trash collection, where the garbage and trash collection cost is not included in rent, site rent, condo fee, or other fee, or included in another utility cost. Costs are not collected for vacant units, but information is collected on whether the unit would be billed separately for garbage and trash collection or if the garbage and trash collection costs would be included in the rent, condo fee, or other charges.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro, 2019 National, 2019 Metro, 2017 National, 2017 Metro, 2015 National, 2015 Metro
Description: Monthly water amount
Response Codes: 0: Unit does not use water||1: Vacant home: billed separately||2: Occupied or vacant home: included in the rent, site rent, condominium fee, other fee, or other utility bill||3: Occupied home: provided free of charge||4 : 832: $4 to $832||833: $833 or more||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: In the last year, what was the total cost for water supply and sewage disposal?
User Notes: Monthly water amount represents average monthly costs paid for water supply and sewage disposal. Respondents are asked to estimate the total cost for their water supply and sewage disposal in the past 12 months. The total amount for the past 12 months is divided by 12 to obtain the average monthly amount. Amounts are for occupied units that pay for their water supply and sewage disposal, where the water supply and sewage disposal cost is not included in rent, site rent, condo fee, or other fee, or included in another utility cost. Costs are not collected for vacant units, but information is collected on whether the unit would be billed separately for water supply and sewage disposal or if the water supply and sewage disposal costs would be included in the rent, condo fee, or other charges.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro, 2021 National, 2021 Metro
Description: How payments vary over the length of the mortgage
Response Codes: 1: Mortgage payment does not change||2: Mortgage payment changes||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' and TENURE = '1' and LOANTYPE in ('1' '2')
User Notes: Respondents are first asked VARY (Are the payments on this mortgage or loan the same during the whole length of the mortgage or loan?), and if they reply no, then asked HOWVARY (Why do the payments in the mortgage or loan change?). Starting in 2015, HOWVARY's answer categories were randomized in the instrument. In 2023, respondents were no longer able to select all that apply for HOWVARY. Instead, they were asked to select the main reason why the payments change.

Description: Flag indicating what forced the respondent, who moved in last two years, to move
Response Codes: 1: Forced to move due to landlord, bank or other financial institution, or the government||2: Forced to move because of natural disaster or fire||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' and ((([interview year] - 2) < MOVE) or ((([interview year] - 2) = MOVE) and [month of survey] <= MOVM)) and RESPONDENT = '1' and MOVFORCE = '1'
User Notes: In 2015, only one question was asked (MOVFORCE - Were you forced to move by a landlord, a bank or other financial institution, the government, or because of a disaster or fire?). In 2017 and later, the single MOVFORCE item was replaced with two items: MOVFORCE2 and MOVDISAS. MOVWHY differentiates between those two reasons for moving. In 2017 and later, MOVFORCE2 used the question text: "Were you forced to move by a landlord, a bank or other financial institution, or the government?" In 2017 through 2021, MOVDISAS used the question text: "Were you forced to move because of a disaster or fire?" In 2023, MOVDISAS used the question text: "Were you forced to move because of a natural disaster or fire, whether the fire started inside or outside of your home?"

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro
Description: Type of outdoor pool safety measures
Response Codes: 1: Has fenced pool||2: Has non-fenced pool||3: Has pool, don't know if pool is fenced||4: No access to outdoor pool||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' and SPLITSAMP = '2' and (SAFEU7KD = '1' or SAFEU7KD = 'N')
User Notes: POOLSAFE is determined using POOLACC (Do you have access to an outdoor swimming pool on this property?) and POOLFEN (Is there a fence at least 4 feet tall that goes all the way around the pool with a gate that closes and locks automatically?) Multifamily complexes that have a pool are assumed to have a fence (i.e., POOLSAFE = 1). This item is part of the Group 2 Topical modules; use SP2WEIGHT to create weighted estimates.

The 2013 PUF has this variable, but with different response codes.

Description: Difficulty affording housing payments in last 12 months
Response Codes: 1: Very difficult||2: Moderately difficult||3: A little difficult||4: Not at all difficult||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: Overall, in the last 12 months, how difficult was it for you to afford your housing payments?
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' and SPLITSAMP = '1' and (TENURE = '2' or MORTSTAT in ('2' '3' '4' '5'))
User Notes: This item is part of the Group 1 Topical modules; use SP1WEIGHT to create weighted estimates.

Survey Years: 2023 National, 2023 Metro
Description: Number of months missed housing payments in last 12 months
Response Codes: 1: Yes, 1 or 2 months||2: Yes, some months but not every month||3: Yes, almost every month||4: Yes, every month||5: Yes, number of months not reported||6: No payments behind||M or -9: Not reported||N or -6: Not applicable
Question Text: See User Notes
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' and SPLITSAMP = '1' and (TENURE = '2' or MORTSTAT in ('2' '3' '4' '5'))
User Notes: HIBEHINDFRQ is determined using HIBEHIND (Was there ever a time when you were a month or more behind in making a housing payment?) and HIBFREQ (How often in the last 12 months would you say you were behind on your housing payments?). This item is part of the Group 1 Topical modules; use SP1WEIGHT to create weighted estimates.

Description: Number of people living in unit because nowhere else to stay

Question Text: See User Notes

Question Text: See User Notes
Conditions in Universe: INTSTATUS = '1' and SPLITSAMP = '1' and ((([year of survey] - 1) < MOVE) or ((([year of survey] - 1) = MOVE) and [month of survey] <= MOVM)) and RESPONDENT = '1'
User Notes: HIPREVNUM is determined using HIPREVHO (How long did you live in your previous home?) and HILIVNUM (About how many months would you say you lived there?). This item is part of the Group 1 Topical modules; use SP1WEIGHT to create weighted estimates.
